question: The following image shows students taking the imperial examination in China c.960-1279 CE. <image 1> Why were Japan's early attempts at introducing the Chinese-style imperial exam largely unsuccessful?
options: ['The Japanese were unable to adapt to the Chinese style of examination.', 'Merchants resisted, fearing that efficient administrators would lead to increased taxes.', 'Japanese nobles feared that their power base would be weakened.', 'Christian missionaries discouraged the adoption of pagan practices.']
description: The image depicts a scene from ancient China, specifically showing students taking the imperial examination. The setting appears to be an outdoor courtyard with several students seated at desks arranged in rows. The students are dressed in traditional attire, and there are buildings in the background, likely part of an educational institution or examination hall. The overall atmosphere suggests a formal and structured environment typical of the imperial examination system used in China during the period of 960-1279 CE.
